self_assessment.question: Can you explain the difference between probability and likelihood?
self_assessment.hint: Probability: given parameters, what's the chance of observing data? Likelihood: given data, how well do parameters explain it?

self_assessment.question: When would you use a t-test vs. a Mann-Whitney U test?
self_assessment.hint: t-test assumes normality, Mann-Whitney is non-parametric

self_assessment.question: What's wrong with this statement: 'There's a 95% probability that the true mean lies in this confidence interval'?
self_assessment.hint: Confidence intervals are about the procedure, not the specific interval

common_misconceptions.reality: Correlation only shows association. Causation requires additional evidence like randomized experiments or causal inference methods.
common_misconceptions.example: Ice cream sales and drowning deaths are correlated, but ice cream doesn't cause drowning - both increase in summer.

common_misconceptions.misconception: A p-value is the probability that the null hypothesis is true
common_misconceptions.reality: p-value is the probability of observing data this extreme IF the null hypothesis is true.
common_misconceptions.correct_interpretation: p-value = P(data | H₀), not P(H₀ | data)

common_misconceptions.misconception: 95% confidence interval means 95% probability the true value is in the interval
common_misconceptions.reality: 95% of such intervals constructed this way will contain the true value. Any specific interval either does or doesn't contain it.
common_misconceptions.frequentist_vs_bayesian: This is why some prefer Bayesian credible intervals

common_misconceptions.reality: With large enough samples, tiny differences become statistically significant but may not matter practically.
common_misconceptions.solution: Always consider effect sizes and confidence intervals, not just p-values

career_impact.why_critical: Statistics is the foundation of data science. It separates those who can only run algorithms from those who can design experiments, interpret results, and make data-driven decisions.
career_impact.competitive_advantage: Deep statistical thinking allows you to solve problems that require more than just applying ML algorithms - you can design proper experiments, avoid statistical pitfalls, and communicate uncertainty effectively.
